questions.text: Which of the following components of epidemiology is associated with descriptive epidemiology?

choices.text: Disease determinants
Disease distribution
Disease frequency
Both A and C

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Disease distribution

Explanation:

Definition of epidemiology (by John M Last ): Study of frequency, distribution and determinants of health-related states/events or disease in population groups and application of the study to control health problems.

Components of epidemiology:

  • Disease distribution:
    • Disease distribution is according to time, place, and person.
    • Descriptive epidemiology helps form an aetiological hypothesis
    • Eg. case study, case series (Option B)
  • Disease determinants:
    • Answers to why and how of the disease [i.e. Identifying causes and risk factors of disease].
    • Helps in testing a hypothesis.
    • Eg. ecological study, cross sectional study.. case control study, cohort study (Option A)
  • Disease frequency:
    • Incidence and prevalence of a disease, expressed in the form of rate, proportion, and ratio. (Option C)

questions.text: What are rate, ratio, and proportion commonly referred to as in the context of epidemiology?

choices.text: Tools for risk assessment
Tools for biostatistical analysis
Basic tools of measurement in epidemiology
Measures of central tendency

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Basic tools of measurement in epidemiology

Explanation:

In epidemiology, tools of measurement show disease frequency/magnitude. They are rate, ratio, and proportion.

  • Rate: Numerator/Denominator x 1000 or 10,000 or 1,00,000 where the numerator is a part of the denominator
  • Ratio: Numerator/Denominator where the numerator is not a part of the denominator
  • Proportion: Numerator/Denominator x 100 where the numerator is a part of the denominator

 

Definitions in Epidemiology

Measure Definition
Ratio A comparison of two numbers, e.g., male to female ratio
Proportion A type of ratio where the numerator is part of the denominator, e.g., % of infected
Rate A proportion with a time component, e.g., incidence rate per year

 

These are essential for calculating incidence, prevalence, case fatality rate, etc.

Tools for risk assessment (Option A): Incorrect because while rates and ratios are used in risk assessment, they are more fundamentally classified as measurement tools.

Tools for biostatistical analysis (Option B): Incorrect because this is too broad and indirect—while they are used in biostatistics, their primary role in epidemiology is measurement.

Measures of central tendency (Option D): Incorrect because central tendency refers to mean, median, and mode, not rate, ratio, or proportion.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a ‘Rate’ in epidemiology?

choices.text: The number of students who prefer chocolate ice cream to vanilla ice cream in a class.
The percentage of female students in a school.
The number of deaths from lung cancer per 100,000 people in a year.
The ratio of males to females in a population.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The number of deaths from lung cancer per 100,000 people in a year.

Explanation:

A ‘Rate’ measures how often an event (like disease or death) happens in a specific group of people during a set time period.

  • It's calculated by dividing the number of times the event happened (numerator) by the total number of people at risk (denominator) and multiplying by a standard factor, such as 1,000, 10,000, or 100,000.
  • Example:

Incidence rate = (Total number of new cases / Total population at risk) x 1000

Types of Rate

Description

Examples

Crude Rates

Actual observed rates are calculated directly from raw data without adjustments.

Crude birth rate: Number of births / Total population * 1000

Specific Rates

Rates that focus on specific causes

Tuberculosis mortality rate: Deaths due to TB / Population at risk * 100,000

Standardised Rates

Rates are adjusted to account for differences in the composition of populations when comparing different groups or populations.

Age-standardized mortality rate.

The number of students who prefer chocolate ice cream to vanilla ice cream in a class represents a simple comparison or proportion within a group at a specific time without considering a time period. (Option A)

The percentage of female students in a school is a proportion that describes the makeup of a population at a point in time, not a rate over time. (Option B)

The ratio of males to females in a population refers to a ratio that compares two distinct groups at a specific time without the element of time passage. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct formula for calculating the Sex Ratio?

choices.text: (Number of females / Number of males) x 100
(Number of males / Number of females) x 100
(Number of females / Total population) x 100
(Number of females / Number of males) x 1000

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) (Number of females / Number of males) x 1000

Explanation:

A ratio compares two distinct groups by dividing the value of one group by the other, where the numerator is not part of the denominator.

E.g., Sex Ratio: This ratio compares explicitly the number of females to the number of males within a population. It is typically expressed per 1000 males.

Sex Ratio = (Number of females/Number of males​) × 1000

(Number of females / Number of males) x 100 (Option A): resembles the Sex Ratio but uses a multiplier of 100 instead of the standard 1000.

(Number of males / Number of females) x 100 (Option B): This inverts the relationship, calculating the number of males per 100 females rather than the standard Sex Ratio. 

(Number of females / Total population) x 100 (Option C): This formula calculates the proportion of females in the total population, not the sex ratio. It is an example of a proportion where the numerator is included in the denominator.

questions.text: A town with a population of 10,000 people is experiencing an influenza outbreak. Over the past two weeks, 500 cases have been reported. What is the proportion of the population affected by influenza during these two weeks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 5%

Explanation:

Based on the given information, the number of influenza cases over two weeks was 500, and the total population was 10,000

Therefore, proportion= (500/10000)x100 = 5%

Thus, 5% of the town's population was affected by influenza during the two weeks.

questions.text: In a small town with a population of 2,00,000 people, a public health team is investigating an outbreak of gastroenteritis. Over one month, 1,500 new cases of gastroenteritis are reported. Calculate the incidence rate of gastroenteritis in the above population.

choices.text: 0.75 per 1,000 population
1.5 per 1,000 population
7.5 per 1,000 population
15 per 1,000 population

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 7.5 per 1,000 population

Explanation:

Based on the above information, the total number of new cases: is 1,500, and the population at risk: is 200,000.

Therefore, Incidence = (1500/200000)x1000 = 7.5 per 1000 population.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a primary use of disease incidence?

choices.text: Identifying and monitoring disease trends over time
Evaluating the effectiveness of public health interventions
Helps to determine the efficacy of primary prevention of the disease
Determining the genetic predisposition of individuals to certain diseases

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Determining the genetic predisposition of individuals to certain diseases.

Explanation:

While the incidence rate is important for many public health purposes, it is not typically used to determine individual genetic predispositions, which are usually studied through genetic and family history data.

Uses of incidence rates:

  1. Identifying and monitoring disease trends over time (Option A)
  2. Evaluating the effectiveness of public health interventions (Option B)
  3. Helps to determine the efficacy of primary prevention of the disease (Option C)
  4. Used as a health status indicator.

questions.text: A health survey reported 5 confirmed cases of Chronic Kidney Disease in a community of 100 people in December. By the end of January, 3 new cases of CKD were diagnosed. Prevalence was reported for Dec and Jan, particularly on Jan 31st. Which of the following statements is true in this scenario?

choices.text: Point prevalence is more than period prevalence
Point prevalence is less than period prevalence
Point prevalence is equal to period prevalence
Point prevalence and Period prevalence cannot be compared

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Point prevalence is equal to period prevalence

Explanation:

  • The total number of cases of CKD (8 in this scenario) will be the same in the defined period (Dec-Jan) and at a point (Jan 31st) since CKD is a chronic disease.
  • The former CKD patients were alive in that specific time period (Dec- Jan), because CKD can lead to death due to variety of causes .
  • Hence, Prevalence = (8/100) = 0.08

questions.text: During a food festival in a small town, 200 people attended a barbecue event. Within 48 hours, 60 attendees developed symptoms of food poisoning. Local health officials want to measure the extent of the outbreak among those who attended the event. What is the term used to describe the proportion of people who developed symptoms out of all the attendees?

choices.text: Attack rate
Secondary attack rate
Case fatality rate
Prevalence rate

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Attack rate

Explanation:

The attack rate is the most appropriate measure in this scenario. It represents the proportion of exposed individuals who develop the disease during a specified time period. In this case, we want to measure the extent of food poisoning among those who attended the barbecue event.

To calculate the attack rate:

Number of new cases / Total number of people at risk × 100 = 60 / 200 × 100 = 30%

Secondary attack rate (Option B):

This is a measure of commuicability/transmisibility of a disease. It's typically used for person-to-person transmitted diseases, not for a common source outbreak like food poisoning at an event.

Case fatality rate (Option C) :

This is a measure of severity/virulence of a disease. It is the proportion of individuals who die from a specific disease among those diagnosed with it. It is not applicable here, as we are not provided with death data. We are focused on the extent of the outbreak, not its severity.

Prevalence rate (Option D): This measures the proportion of people with a particular condition at a specific time. It's unsuitable for this acute outbreak scenario, as we're interested in new cases that developed after a specific exposure, not the total number of existing cases in the population.

questions.text: A research team conducted a study containing 5,000 participants who were free of diabetes at the start of the study for 10 years. During the follow-up period, 300 participants developed Type 2 diabetes. Which of the following measures best describes the outcome assessed in this study?

choices.text: Includes both new and existing cases of the disease
Follow up not required
Independent of the duration of the illness
Estimates the burden of the disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Independent of the duration of the disease

Explanation:

This study is a prospective cohort study as it uses participants who are free of disease and then finds the incidence rate after 10 years.

questions.text: A public health department is implementing a new vaccination program to prevent the spread of a contagious disease in a community. After several years of the vaccination program, which of the following outcomes is most likely to occur due to the successful vaccination program?

choices.text: Decrease in the prevalence of the disease
Increase in the prevalence of the disease
Decrease in the incidence of the disease
Incidence of the disease remain the same

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Decrease the incidence of the disease

Explanation:

A new vaccination program is implemented to prevent the spread of a contagious disease in a community, which decreases the incidence of the disease.

Relationship between prevalence and incidence:

Prevalence (P) ∝ Incidence (I) x Duration (D)
